questions.text: Name the staining technique used to demonstrate the arrow marked structure in the image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The structure shown in the image is bacterial flagella.
Fontana stain – flagella – Silver impregnation stain
Bacterial endospores are stained by Fulton stain.
Chan stain – Bacterial cell wall
Muir stain – Capsule

questions.text: All the following organisms exhibit the motility shown in the image except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Image shown here is Swarming motility in medium
Exhibited by Proteus, C. tetani, Vibrio parahemolyticus, and C. jejuni
B. anthracis is non motile

questions.text: A 72-year-old male undergoes total knee replacement. Two months later, he develops low-grade fever, joint pain, and prosthetic loosening. Joint aspirate culture reveals Gram-positive cocci in clusters that are catalase-positive and coagulase-negative. Which normal skin flora is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Staphylococcus epidermidis is a normal skin flora and a common cause of prosthetic joint infections, forming biofilms on medical implants.

questions.text: As per the Spaulding’s classification the item shown in the image is categorized as
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The item shown in the image is Rigid endoscope
It contact with sterile tissues
As per the Spauldings classification, it comes under critical category

questions.text: All the following belongs to Bioterrorism Agent Category C except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Ebola belongs to Category A.

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy presents with facial puffiness, hematuria, and hypertension 3 weeks after a streptococcal throat infection. Kidney biopsy shows subepithelial immune complex deposits on electron microscopy and a "lumpy-bumpy" pattern on immunofluorescence. Which hypersensitivity reaction is responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is caused by immune complex deposition in the glomeruli, leading to complement activation and inflammation (Type III reaction).

questions.text: Name the reaction shown in the image
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Image shown here is one dimension double diffusion test – Oakley Fulthorpe reaction

questions.text: All the features suggestive of a child suffering from an immunodeficiency disorder as shown in the image except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) It’s a case of Digeorge syndrome. Absence of T cells, Cleft palate, Cardiac defects like TOF, Abnormal facies, Thymic aplasia, Hypocalcemia are the features. Due to deletion in 22q11

questions.text: Pathophysiology shown in the picture belongs to which type of hypersensitivity
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Antibody produced against acetylcholine receptor - Myasthenia gravis.
It comes under Type II HSR.

questions.text: Decay accelerating factor deficiency leads to
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

CD55 deficiency, also called DAF deficiency or CHAPLE syndrome, is a rare disease characterized by complement-mediated autoimmune hemolysis and paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria. 
When CD55 is absent, the complement system attacks red blood cells and causes them to be destroyed.
C1, C2, C4 – SLE
C5b-C9 – Toxoplasma
C1 inhibitor - HANE

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with high fever, hypotension, diffuse erythroderma, and multi-organ failure. She reports recent use of tampons. Blood cultures are negative, but vaginal swab culture grows Gram-positive cocci in clusters that are catalase-positive and coagulase-positive. Which of the following virulence factors is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Staphylococcus aureus produces TSST-1, a superantigen that causes toxic shock syndrome (TSS) by activating T cells and cytokine release.

questions.text: A 58-year-old diabetic male presents with rapidly spreading skin necrosis, high fever, and hypotension. The affected skin is dusky with bullae. Gram stain of wound fluid shows Gram-positive cocci in chains, and culture is bacitracin-sensitive. Which virulence factor is responsible for the extensive tissue destruction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Streptococcus pyogenes causes necrotizing fasciitis, where SpeB (a cysteine protease) mediates extensive tissue destruction.

choices.text: Acting on 60s Ribosome – Inhibits protein synthesis
Acting on EF2 – Inhibits protein synthesis

questions.text: Choose the correct MoA of the toxin responsible for a clinical condition shown in the image.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

It’s a case of Diphtheria caused by Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
MoA of toxin is ADP ribosylation of EF2 and inhibits protein synthesis.

questions.text: A 40-year-old farmer presents for evaluation of a lesion on his arm. The lesion originally started as a painless pruritic papule but enlarged over the last several days. The Gram stain examination of the lesion is shown in the image. What may be the colony appearance seen under microscope on the selective medium for this pathogen.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

It’s a case of cutaneous anthrax and image shown here is Gram positive bacilli.
In PLET medium by naked eye examination, it produces frosted glass colonies.
Under microscope – Medusa head colonies.

questions.text: Pig bel is due to which serotype of the alpha and beta toxin produced by the specific Pathogen?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Enteritis necroticans or Pig bel  is a segmental necrotizing infection of the jejunum and ileum caused by Clostridium perfringens, Type C. 
The disease occurs sporadically in parts of Asia, Africa, and the South Pacific, where it primarily affects children with severe protein malnutrition

questions.text: All the following are belonging to Non-photo chromogens except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Non chromogens are M. avium, M. intracellularae, M. xenopi, M. ulcerans and M. paratuberculosis.

questions.text: Choose the correct bacteria and selective medium
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


Nocardia – BCYE agar
Burkholderia pseudomallei – Ashdown medium
Clostridioides difficile - CCFA
Brucella abortus – Castaneda biphasic medium

questions.text: 28-year-old man admitted with a road traffic accident and wound is shown in the image. As per the history he was vaccinated 4 years before for tetanus. As per the current guideline what should be the appropriate prophylactic measurement for tetanus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

It’s a case of contaminated wound.
Previous vaccination done with in 5 years.
So no need of tetanus vaccination and TIg

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy noticed the development of a greenish ear discharge several days after swimming in a public pool. Culture shown in the image. Choose the false statement regarding the pathogen responsible for his condition.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Colony morphology and the clinical scenario suggestive of swimmer’s ear caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa.
It is a non-fermenter which utilizes the sugars oxidatively.
Exotoxin A acts against EF2 inhibits protein synthesis.

questions.text: Fish in stream arrangement is seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Haemophilus ducreyi is a fastidious gram-negative coccobacillus bacteria, which causes the sexually transmitted disease chancroid, a major cause of genital ulceration in developing countries characterized by painful sores on the genitalia. 
H. ducreyi gram stain appears as "school of fish” or tram track appearance

choices.text: Brucella abortus is so named because it causes abortion in sheep and cattle
Epididymo-orchitis is a feature of infection in men
A 2-week course of doxycycline is adequate treatment in most cases
Is a cause of splenic abscess

questions.text: All the following statements are true regarding Brucellosis except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


Brucellae are sensitive to a number of oral antibiotics and aminoglycosides. 
The combination of tetracycline and doxycycline is effective against most species of Brucella. 
Relapse is common on therapy with a single drug. 
Most of the patients respond to a 6-week course of therapy with a combination of rifampin and doxycycline given orally.

questions.text: Human monocytic ehrlichiosis is caused by
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ehrlichia chaffeensis – Human monocytic ehrlichiosis
Anaplasma phagocytophilum – Human granulocytic ehrlichiosis
Neorickettsia sennetsu  - Human lymphocytic ehrlichiosis
Morula formation is diagnostic.

questions.text: In diagnosis of syphilis, which method needs compound light microscope
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

VDRL needs compound light microscopy to visualize the flocculation reaction.
TPI needs Dark field microscope.
RPR and TPPA results visualized by naked eye.

questions.text: A girl from Surat presented to OPD with fever, hypotension, malaise and axillary and inguinal lymphadenopathy. Culture in glucose broth shown in the picture. Based on the image choose the most likely vector for this disease.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

In broth, Y. pestis produces a flocculent growth with granular deposit at the bottom and along the sides of the tube, with little or no turbidity. On prolonged incubation, a delicate pellicle may form at the surface. 
Y. pestis produces a characteristic growth when grown in a flask of broth with oil or ghee (clarified butter) floated on top (ghee broth). 
The growth in the medium appears to hang down into the broth from the surface, resembling stalactites (stalactite growth)
Vector is Rat flea (X. cheopsis) and the mode of transmission is by bite of the

questions.text: Motility exhibited by the pathogen causing a clinical picture shown in the image is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Target rash suggestive of Lyme disease
Caused by Borrelia burgdoferi
It exhibits lashing motility.

questions.text: A 5-day-old neonate presents with seizures, fever, and irritability. MRI shows temporal lobe encephalitis. Tzanck smear of vesicular fluid reveals multinucleated giant cells . In this case, Which virus is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Neonatal HSV-2 infection, acquired during vaginal delivery, commonly presents as disseminated disease or encephalitis with temporal lobe involvement. Tzanck smear detects multinucleated giant cells.
Usually Encephalitis caused by HHV1 and meningitis by HHV 2.

questions.text: A 30-year-old NRI man bitten by a bat presents with hydrophobia, agitation, and coma. Autopsy reveals Negri bodies in the hippocampus. Which is the most likely viral morphology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Rabies virus (Rhabdovirus) is a bullet-shaped, helical RNA virus that causes fatal encephalitis.

questions.text: A nurse from West Africa presents with high fever, multi-organ failure, and hemorrhagic diathesis. Electron microscopy reveals a filamentous, pleomorphic RNA virus. Which virus is responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Ebola virus (Filovirus) causes severe hemorrhagic fever, diagnosed via RT-PCR or electron microscopy.

questions.text: A 13-year-old child with a history of measles infection at age 2 presents with progressive cognitive decline, ataxia, and myoclonus. EEG shows periodic bursts of high-amplitude waves. CSF PCR reveals high levels of measles virus RNA. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

SSPE is a delayed CNS complication of measles due to a defective, persistent viral strain affecting neurons. 
EEG shows periodic complexes, and CSF PCR confirms measles virus RNA.

questions.text: A 32-year-old asymptomatic male has the following serology results: HBsAg: Positive, Anti-HBs: Negative, HBeAg: Negative, Anti-HBe: Positive, HBV DNA: Low. What is the most likely status?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

HBsAg positivity with low HBV DNA and negative HBeAg suggests chronic inactive carrier state.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman develops fever, thrombocytopenia, shock, and spontaneous bleeding. She had previous Dengue infection. Which immune mechanism is responsible for severe disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

ADE occurs when non-neutralizing antibodies from a prior infection enhance viral uptake, worsening vascular leakage.
Exhibited by Dengue virus

questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with severe diarrhea and dehydration. Stool ELISA is positive for dsRNA virus. EM shown in the image. Which virulence factor is responsible for the diarrhea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

It’s a case of rota virus. 
Rotavirus NSP4 toxin induces chloride secretion, causing watery diarrhea.

questions.text: A forest worker from Eastern Europe presents with fever, hypotension, and acute renal failure. Serology detects RNA virus with a segmented genome. Which virus is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Hantavirus (HFRS subtype) is a Bunyavirus that causes hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome (HFRS) in Europe and Asia, transmitted by rodent urine.
Segmented RNA with 3 segments.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy from Pakistan develops acute flaccid paralysis with asymmetric limb weakness. CSF shows elevated WBCs and protein, normal glucose. PCR detects a positive-sense RNA virus. Which virus is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Poliovirus (Picornavirus) causes asymmetric flaccid paralysis, often seen in non-vaccinated regions.

questions.text: A lung transplant recipient develops severe pneumonia and diffuse alveolar hemorrhage. A bronchoalveolar lavage sample is positive for enveloped, linear double-stranded DNA virus. It exhibits a typical structure in biopsy as shown in the image. Which virus is responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Cytomegalovirus causes necrotizing pneumonia in immunocompromised hosts. Owl’s eye inclusions are seen in infected cells.

questions.text: A 32-year-old HIV-positive man (CD4: 40 cells/µL) presents with seizures and altered mental status. MRI shows multiple ring-enhancing brain lesions. Serology detects IgG antibodies against a protozoan which is positive for Sabin Feld man dye test. .Which of the following is the first-line treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Sabin Feld man dye test is gold standard test to diagnose Toxoplasma gondii.
Toxoplasma gondii causes toxoplasmic encephalitis in AIDS patients. 
The standard treatment is sulfadiazine + pyrimethamine + leucovorin.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with bloody diarrhea and weight loss. Colonoscopy shows flask-shaped ulcers. Stool microscopy shown in the image. What is the diagnostic stage?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

E. histolytica causes flask-shaped ulcers and trophozoites with ingested RBCs as shown in the image.
Diagnostic stages – Trophozoite with ingested RBCs and Quadrinucleate cyst.
Infective stage – Quadrinucleate cyst.

questions.text: A 26-year-old presents with high fever, jaundice, and cerebral dysfunction. Peripheral blood smear (Giemsa stain) shown in the image. Which species is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

P. falciparum is identified by banana-shaped gametocytes and multiple ring forms per RBC, causing severe malaria.
Accole formation is diagnostic.

questions.text: A 45-year-old Brazilian man presents with constipation, difficulty swallowing, and cardiomyopathy. Blood smear shown in the image. Which parasite is responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Image shown here is trypomastigote and case scenario suggestive of T.cruzi.
T. cruzi causes Chagas disease, leading to megacolon, megaesophagus, and myocarditis.

questions.text: A young boy from Sudan presents with fever, pancytopenia, and hepatosplenomegaly. Bone marrow aspirate shows intracellular amastigotes. Choose the correct selective medium.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Leishmania donovani causes visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar) with amastigotes inside macrophages.
Selective medium is NNN medium ( Novy – Nicolle- Mc Neal medium)

questions.text: A 60-year-old African farmer presents with vision loss and pruritic skin nodules. Skin biopsy stained with Giemsa reveals microfilariae as shown in the image. Which parasite is responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Unsheathed microfilariae with no nucleus extended to tail tip suggestive of O. volvulus.
Onchocerca volvulus causes river blindness, transmitted by blackflies.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with chronic diarrhea and rectal prolapse. Stool microscopy reveals barrel-shaped eggs with bipolar plugs. What is the most likely parasite?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Trichuris trichiura (whipworm) causes rectal prolapse and is diagnosed by barrel-shaped eggs with bipolar plugs.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man from Thailand presents with chronic cough, hemoptysis, and eosinophilia. Chest X-ray shows cavitary lung lesions, and stool microscopy reveals operculated eggs. Which parasite is responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Paragonimus westermani causes paragonimiasis, a lung fluke infection that mimics TB with hemoptysis and cavitary lesions.
It causes endemic hemoptysis
Operculated egg is diagnostic.

questions.text: A hunter from Alaska develops periorbital edema, myalgia, fever, and eosinophilia after eating undercooked bear meat. Muscle biopsy shows encysted larvae. Which parasite is responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Trichinella spiralis causes trichinosis, presenting with muscle cysts, myositis, and periorbital edema.

questions.text: A 52-year-old fisherman presents with fatigue, glossitis, and paresthesias. Peripheral blood smear shows macrocytic anemia, and serum Vitamin B12 is low. Stool examination reveals proglottids with central uterine branching. Choose the infective stage of this pathogen.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Diphyllobothrium latum (fish tapeworm) absorbs Vitamin B12, leading to megaloblastic anemia. It is acquired from raw freshwater fish and has central uterine branching in proglottids.
Infective stage is plerocercoid larvae.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with diabetes mellitus presents with a chronic cough, weight loss, and hemoptysis. A chest X-ray reveals a cavitary lesion in the upper lobe of the right lung. A bronchoalveolar lavage sample is stained with Gomori methenamine silver stain shown in the image. Choose the best test to determine the invasiveness of this pathogen.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The image likely shows acute-angle branching septate hyphae, characteristic of Aspergillus. 
This fungal infection can form aspergillomas (fungal balls) in pre-existing cavities or cause chronic pulmonary aspergillosis, especially in diabetics and immunocompromised patients.
Assy for invasiveness is Galactomannan assay.

questions.text: A 40-year-old HIV-positive patient presents with dyspnea and a dry cough. Bronchoalveolar lavage stained with Giemsa stain shows foamy alveolar exudates with cysts. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Pneumocystis jirovecii causes Pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP), commonly seen in AIDS patients with CD4 <200 cells/μL.
BAL microscopy – Borken ping ball cysts are diagnostic.
Treatment – Cotrimoxazole.

questions.text: A 42-year-old burn patient develops fever and skin lesions with necrotic centers. Blood cultures grow banana-shaped conidia as shown in the image and resistant to amphotericin B. What is the most likely organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Fusarium causes fungemia in burn patients, producing banana-shaped macroconidia and intrinsic amphotericin B resistance.

questions.text: A 47-year-old farmer presents with a chronic cough, verrucous skin lesions, and osteomyelitis. A biopsy stained with PAS stain reveals broad-based budding yeast. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Blastomyces dermatitidis causes pulmonary, cutaneous, and osteoarticular infections, with broad-based budding yeast on histopathology.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) patient presents with black necrotic nasal eschar and orbital swelling. A biopsy stained with H&E reveals broad non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching. Which of the following organisms is most likely responsible?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Mucorales fungi (e.g., Rhizopus) cause rhinocerebral mucormycosis, especially in diabetics, producing broad non-septate hyphae with right-angle branching.
